a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "binomial n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "binomial 30 27 = 4060"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{30}{27}$. The final Answer is 4060
 ### Proof
 $\dbinom{30}{27}=\dbinom{30}{3}=\dfrac{30 \times 29 \times 28}{3!} = \boxed{4060}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "binomial n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "binomial 30 27 = 4060"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Compute the binomial coefficient $\binom{30}{27}$ using the formula $\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$. The final answer is 4060.

a_1.formal problem:

and h1 : "k = 27"
shows  "binomial n k = 4060"

 *)

fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 30"
and h1 : "k = 27"
shows  "binomial n k = 4060"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. binomial n k = (if k = 0 \<or> k = n then 1 else binomial (n - 1) k + binomial (n - 1) (k - 1))"
shows  "binomial 30 27 = 4060"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{30}{27}$. The final Answer is 4060
 ### Proof
 $\dbinom{30}{27}=\dbinom{30}{3}=\dfrac{30 \times 29 \times 28}{3!} = \boxed{4060}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n k binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. binomial n k = (if k = 0 \<or> k = n then 1 else binomial (n - 1) k + binomial (n - 1) (k - 1))"
shows  "binomial 30 27 = 4060"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the value of the binomial coefficient $\binom{30}{27}$. The final answer is 4060.
